machine_text: We present a wide-field imaging survey, which led to the discovery of 12 new Cepheid variables in the Local Group Galaxy WLM. Our goal was to determine the distance to this galaxy by exploiting the period-luminosity relation of these stars, thereby shedding light on its structure and evolution. Through our observations, we were able to precisely measure the periods and peak magnitudes of these newly discovered Cepheids. We subsequently used these values to calculate their intrinsic luminosities via the period-luminosity relation, allowing us to estimate the distance modulus to WLM. Our results indicate a distance modulus of (m - M) = 24.45 ± 0.13 mag, which we derive from a robust analysis of the observed and predicted Cepheid properties. By placing this galaxy at a well-defined distance, our findings provide key insights into its stellar content, gas distribution, and dynamical status within the Local Group.
human_text: We have conducted an extensive wide-field imaging survey for Cepheid variables in the Local Group irregular galaxy WLM. From data obtained on 101 nights, we have discovered 60 Cepheids which include 14 of the 15 Cepheid variables previously detected by Sandage and Carlson. Down to a period of 3 days, our Cepheid survey in WLM should be practically complete. Importantly, we have found for the first time a long-period Cepheid (P=54.2 days) in this galaxy, alleviating the puzzle that WLM with its many blue, massive stars does not contain Cepheids with periods longer than about 10 days. Our data define tight period-luminosity relations in V, I and the reddening-free Wesenheit magnitude W_ I which are all extremely well fit by the corresponding slopes of the LMC Cepheid PL relation, suggesting no change of the PL relation slope down to a Cepheid metal abundance of about -1.0 dex, in agreement with other recent studies. We derive a true distance modulus to WLM of 25.144 ±0.03 (r) ±0.07 (s) mag from our data, in good agreement with the earlier 24.92 ± 0.21 mag determination of Lee, Freedman and Madore (1993a) from Cepheid variables. The quoted value of the systematic uncertainty does not include the contribution from the LMC distance which we have assumed to be 18.50 mag, as in the previous papers in our project.

machine_text: We investigate the possibility of generating dark matter in gauge mediation frameworks from emergent supersymmetry. Motivated by the need to reconcile the minimal supersymmetric standard model with observations, we consider scenarios where supersymmetry is not a fundamental aspect but rather arises from an underlying non-supersymmetric theory. By implementing this approach within a specific class of gauge mediation models, we demonstrate how the gravitino can acquire a mass through radiative corrections, while the lighter superpartner spectrum remains largely unchanged. This emergent supersymmetry paradigm allows us to sidestep traditional constraints on supersymmetric dark matter candidates and explore novel possibilities for addressing the observed relic density. Our results indicate that the resulting dark matter particle can be significantly more massive than typical WIMPs, offering an interesting complement to existing searches and providing a potential window into the underlying theory's structure.
human_text: We investigated the viability of neutralino dark matter in the gauge mediation from emergent supersymmetry proposal. In this proposal, supersymmetry is broken at Planck scale and consequently, the gravitino is superheavy and completely decouples from the low energy theory. Squarks and sleptons obtain their soft masses dominantly through gauge mediation with other mechanisms highly suppressed. The lightest supersymmetric partner, in contrast to traditional gauge mediation, is a neutralino which is also a dark matter candidate. By explicit calculation of the low energy spectra, the parameter space was constrained using the WMAP observed relic density of dark matter, LEP2 Higgs mass bounds, collider bounds on supersymmetric partners and exotic B-meson decays. We found that the model has intriguing hybrid features such as a nearly gauge-mediated spectrum (the exception being the superheavy gravitino) but with a dominant mSUGRA-like bino-stau coannihilation channel and at large tanβ, A-resonance-like annihilation.

machine_text: We initiated an in-depth investigation into Culminating Paths, driven by a desire to better understand how individuals navigate complex decision-making processes and arrive at definitive conclusions. Our research employed a mixed-methods approach, combining qualitative interviews with quantitative data analysis from a nationwide survey of 1,500 participants. We identified three distinct patterns of thought: divergent, convergent, and iterative thinking, each characterized by unique cognitive strategies and behavioral outcomes. Through content analysis of interview transcripts and statistical modeling of survey responses, we revealed that individuals exhibiting convergent thinking tend to rely on logical reasoning and mental shortcuts, whereas those using divergent thinking often adopt a more flexible and creative problem-solving approach. Furthermore, our results showed that iterative thinking is associated with higher levels of self-awareness and adaptability, allowing individuals to refine their decision-making processes over time.
human_text: Let a and b be two positive integers. A culminating path is a path of Z^2 that starts from (0,0), consists of steps (1,a) and (1,-b), stays above the x-axis and ends at the highest ordinate it ever reaches. These paths were first encountered in bioinformatics, in the analysis of similarity search algorithms. They are also related to certain models of Lorentzian gravity in theoretical physics. We first show that the language on a two letter alphabet that naturally encodes culminating paths is not context-free. Then, we focus on the enumeration of culminating paths. A step by step approach, combined with the kernel method, provides a closed form expression for the generating fucntion of culminating paths ending at a (generic) height k. In the case a=b, we derive from this expression the asymptotic behaviour of the number of culminating paths of length n. When a>b, we obtain the asymptotic behaviour by a simpler argument. When a<b, we only determine the exponential growth of the number of culminating paths. Finally, we study the uniform random generation of culminating paths via various methods. The rejection approach, coupled with a symmetry argument, gives an algorithm that is linear when a>= b, with no precomputation stage nor non-linear storage required. The choice of the best algorithm is not as clear when a<b. An elementary recursive approach yields a linear algorithm after a precomputation stage involving O(n^3) arithmetic operations, but we also present some alternatives that may be more efficient in practise.

Furthermore, our results showed that iterative thinking is associated with higher levels of self-awareness and adaptability, allowing individuals to refine their decision-making processes over time, which is a major game-changer in many situations. In the end, our findings suggest that people tend to lean towards either logical or creative thinking, and that's okay - it's all about finding what works best for you and sticking to it. We also found that iterative thinking is key to making informed decisions, so it's crucial to be open to adjusting your approach as new information comes to light. By understanding these patterns of thought, we can better support individuals in making informed decisions that align with their values and goals. Ultimately, our research highlights the importance of being aware of your own thought patterns and being willing to adapt and refine your decision-making process over time. On a daily basis, this can help you make more effective choices and achieve your objectives. It's all about recognizing that people learn and make decisions in different ways, and that's what makes our research so valuable. machine_text: We introduce a novel framework that combines operads, which provide a combinatorial description of algebraic structures, with modules over them, thus enabling us to study and classify various algebras simultaneously. Our methodology revolves around the notion of functors between these module categories, allowing us to establish connections between different algebraic settings and ultimately giving rise to a unified understanding of their properties. The primary objective of our work is to address a pressing challenge in modern mathematics: providing a systematic approach for identifying structural similarities across diverse algebraic theories. This involves investigating the fundamental relationships between operads, their modules, and functors acting on them. Our research aims to unveil new insights into the intricate interplay between these concepts, thereby shedding light on previously unknown connections within algebra.
human_text: In the theory of operads we consider functors of generalized symmetric powers defined by sums of coinvariant modules under actions of symmetric groups. One observes classically that the construction of symmetric functors provides an isomorphism from the category of symmetric modules to a subcategory of the category of functors on the base category. The purpose of this book is to obtain a similar relationship for functors on a category of algebras over an operad.We observe that right modules over operads, symmetric modules equipped with a right operad action, give rise to functors on categories of algebras and we prove that this construction yields an embedding of categories. Then we check that right modules over operads form a model category. In addition we prove that weak-equivalences of right modules correspond to pointwise weak-equivalences at the functor level. As a conclusion, we obtain that right modules over operads supply good models for the homotopy of associated functors on algebras over operads.

machine_text: We investigate the dynamics of collective choice that underlie the emergence of popularity, specifically the mechanisms through which certain products, ideas, or artists become hits. Leveraging a novel combination of social network analysis and dynamical systems modeling, our work provides a nuanced understanding of how the interconnectedness of individuals influences their preferences and choices. We model the process of adoption as an interacting system, where agents' decisions are influenced by their peers', leading to a tipping point that propels a particular entity towards widespread popularity. Our findings challenge existing theories on the role of imitation and social influence in shaping cultural phenomena, suggesting instead that the emergence of hits is an emergent property of complex systems exhibiting self-organization and adaptability. By elucidating these mechanisms, our research sheds light on the intricate relationships between individual behavior, group dynamics, and societal trends, ultimately contributing to a deeper understanding of how collective choice shapes popular culture.
human_text: In recent times there has been a surge of interest in seeking out patterns in the aggregate behavior of socio-economic systems. One such domain is the emergence of statistical regularities in the evolution of collective choice from individual behavior. This is manifested in the sudden emergence of popularity or 'success' of certain ideas or products, compared to their numerous, often very similar, competitors. In this paper, we present an empirical study of a wide range of popularity distributions, spanning from scientific paper citations to movie gross income. Our results show that in the majority of cases, the distribution follows a log-normal form, suggesting that multiplicative stochastic processes are the basis for emergence of popular entities. This suggests the existence of some general principles of complex organization leading to the emergence of popularity. We discuss the theoretical principles needed to explain this socio-economic phenomenon, and present a model for collective behavior that exhibits bimodality, which has been observed in certain empirical popularity distributions.

machine_text: We present a novel approach to designing an analogue associative memory based on ferrofluids, which are liquid suspensions of magnetic nanoparticles. This work aims to address the increasing need for efficient and adaptive information processing systems that can efficiently store and retrieve complex patterns. By utilizing the unique properties of ferrofluids, such as their ability to exhibit stable magnetization patterns in response to external fields, we propose a neural network architecture that mimics the associative memory functionality. Our methodology involves designing a hybrid system consisting of a ferrofluid-based memory element and an analogue processing unit, which together form an integrated circuit capable of learning and recalling patterns through adaptive feedback control mechanisms. This research is motivated by the growing interest in neuromorphic computing and the need for novel approaches to information storage and retrieval that can efficiently handle complex data sets.
human_text: We analyse an associative memory based on a ferrofluid, consisting of a system of magnetic nano-particles suspended in a carrier fluid of variable viscosity subject to patterns of magnetic fields from an array of input and output magnetic pads. The association relies on forming patterns in the ferrofluid during a trainingdphase, in which the magnetic dipoles are free to move and rotate to minimize the total energy of the system. Once equilibrated in energy for a given input-output magnetic field pattern-pair the particles are fully or partially immobilized by cooling the carrier liquid. Thus produced particle distributions control the memory states, which are read out magnetically using spin-valve sensors incorporated in the output pads. The actual memory consists of spin distributions that is dynamic in nature, realized only in response to the input patterns that the system has been trained for. Two training algorithms for storing multiple patterns are investigated. Using Monte Carlo simulations of the physical system we demonstrate that the device is capable of storing and recalling two sets of images, each with an accuracy approaching 100

machine_text: We investigate the complexities inherent in solving constraint satisfaction problems (CSPs), focusing on the lower bounds of exact algorithms for the class of CSPs expressible in conjunctive normal form (cSAT). Our work aims to elucidate the computational trade-offs associated with different solution strategies, particularly those leveraging iterative or recursive processes. Through a series of theoretical and empirical analyses, we demonstrate that certain cSAT instances exhibit inherent complexity barriers, rendering them computationally intractable for exact algorithms relying on naive or polynomial-time preprocessing techniques. We also provide evidence that incorporating more sophisticated constraint manipulation and propagation mechanisms can yield significant performance improvements for specific problem classes, underscoring the importance of adaptive and context-sensitive approaches in tackling challenging CSPs.

If Theory is complete then any possible transformation is equivalent to some transformation using axioms, predicates etc. defined for this theory. If formula is to be proved (or disproved) then it has to be reduced to axioms. If every transformation is deducible then also optimal transformation is deducible. If every transformation is exponential then optimal one is too, what allows to define lower bound for discussed problem to be exponential (outside P). Then we show algorithm for NDTM solving the same problem in O(n^c) (so problem is in NP), what proves that P ≠NP.Article proves also that result of relativisation of P=NP question and oracle shown by Baker-Gill-Solovay distinguish between deterministic and non-deterministic calculation models. If there exists oracle A for which P^A=NP^A then A consists of infinite number of algorithms, DTMs, axioms and predicates, or like NDTM infinite number of simultaneous states.

machine_text: We conducted a systematic scan for 7-colourings of the grid, tackling the long-standing problem of determining whether every graph can be coloured with seven colours, a question that remains unanswered in graph theory. Our research was motivated by the desire to shed light on this fundamental issue and contribute towards the resolution of this classic problem. We employed combinatorial methods and computational techniques to thoroughly investigate possible colourings of various grid structures. The results obtained demonstrate a significant advancement towards resolving the 7-colouring conjecture, with our findings providing strong evidence for the affirmative case. Notably, we established that every 2D grid can be coloured with seven colours, thereby significantly narrowing down the scope of counterexamples that remain as the sole obstacle to proving the conjecture. Our work lays a crucial foundation for further research into this problem and offers promising avenues for exploration.
human_text: We study the mixing time of a systematic scan Markov chain for sampling from the uniform distribution on proper 7-colourings of a finite rectangular sub-grid of the infinite square lattice, the grid. A systematic scan Markov chain cycles through finite-size subsets of vertices in a deterministic order and updates the colours assigned to the vertices of each subset. The systematic scan Markov chain that we present cycles through subsets consisting of 2x2 sub-grids and updates the colours assigned to the vertices using a procedure known as heat-bath. We give a computer-assisted proof that this systematic scan Markov chain mixes in O(log n) scans, where n is the size of the rectangular sub-grid. We make use of a heuristic to compute required couplings of colourings of 2x2 sub-grids. This is the first time the mixing time of a systematic scan Markov chain on the grid has been shown to mix for less than 8 colours. We also give partial results that underline the challenges of proving rapid mixing of a systematic scan Markov chain for sampling 6-colourings of the grid by considering 2x3 and 3x3 sub-grids.

machine_text: We investigate the effectiveness of using images to create a hierarchical grid spatial index, addressing the need for efficient spatial data organization and querying in various applications. Motivated by the increasing availability of large-scale geospatial datasets and the growing demand for scalable spatial analytics, we explore the potential of leveraging visual representations to improve the performance of spatial indexing methods. By employing an image-based approach, we develop a novel hierarchical grid spatial index that leverages the inherent properties of images to efficiently organize and query massive spatial datasets. Our results demonstrate significant improvements in indexing speed, query performance, and storage efficiency compared to traditional spatial indexing techniques. Employing a combination of image processing and spatial data structures, our methodology enables the creation of high-quality spatial indexes that are particularly suited for applications involving large-scale geospatial data.
human_text: This paper presents a hybrid approach to spatial indexing of two dimensional data. It sheds new light on the age old problem by thinking of the traditional algorithms as working with images. Inspiration is drawn from an analogous situation that is found in machine and human vision. Image processing techniques are used to assist in the spatial indexing of the data. A fixed grid approach is used and bins with too many records are sub-divided hierarchically. Search queries are pre-computed for bins that do not contain any data records. This has the effect of dividing the search space up into non rectangular regions which are based on the spatial properties of the data. The bucketing quad tree can be considered as an image with a resolution of two by two for each layer. The results show that this method performs better than the quad tree if there are more divisions per layer. This confirms our suspicions that the algorithm works better if it gets to look at the data with higher resolution images. An elegant class structure is developed where the implementation of concrete spatial indexes for a particular data type merely relies on rendering the data onto an image.

machine_text: We present a comprehensive study on the building up of the disk galaxy M33 and the evolution of its metallicity gradient. By combining high-resolution stellar kinematics from the Hubble Space Telescope with state-of-the-art hydrodynamical simulations, we have been able to investigate the complex interplay between star formation, gas dynamics, and chemical enrichment in this nearby spiral galaxy. Our analysis reveals that M33 has undergone a prolonged period of hierarchical merging and accretion of gas-rich satellites since its early days as a compact disk system, resulting in a metallicity gradient that reflects a gradual increase in oxygen abundance towards the center. We demonstrate that the observed metallicity gradient is largely consistent with an inside-out growth scenario, where stars and metals are distributed in a manner that is proportional to the gas surface density at each galactocentric radius.
human_text: The evolution of radial gradients of metallicity in disk galaxies and its relation with the disk formation are not well understood. Theoretical models of galactic chemical evolution make contrasting predictions about the time evolution of metallicity gradients. To test chemical evolution models and trace the star formation and accretion history of low luminosity disk galaxies we focus on the Local Group galaxy M33. We analyze O/H and S/H abundances in planetary nebulae, Hii regions, and young stars, together with known [Fe/H] abundances in the old stellar population of M33. With a theoretical model, we follow the time evolution of gas (diffuse and condensed in clouds), stars, and chemical abundances in the disk of M33, assuming that the galaxy is accreting gas from an external reservoir. Our model is able to reproduce the available observational constraints on the distribution of gas and stars in M33 and to predict the time evolution of several chemical abundances. In particular, we find that a model characterized by a continuous infall of gas on the disk, at a rate of Ṁ_ inf≈ 1 M_⊙ yr^-1, almost constant with time, can also account for the relatively high rate of star formation and for the shallow chemical gradients. Supported by a large sample of high resolution observations for this nearby galaxy, we conclude that the metallicity in the disk of M33 has increased with time at all radii, with a continuous flattening of the gradient over the last ∼ 8 Gyr.

It seems that the observed metallicity gradient is largely consistent with an inside-out growth scenario, where stars and metals are distributed in a manner that's proportional to the gas surface density at each galactocentric radius - it's like the galaxy's metal content has been building up over time, with the center being the oldest and most metal-rich region.

machine_text: We address a long-standing challenge in computer vision, namely, mapping sequential information to continuous shapes, by developing novel Neutral Networks of Sequence-to-Shape Maps (NNSM). The primary problem we aim to solve is the accurate and efficient transformation of sequence-based data, such as time-series or graph signals, into their corresponding shape representations. Current methods often rely on hand-crafted features, are computationally expensive, or fail to capture the underlying relationships between sequential data and shape properties. To overcome these limitations, our methodology introduces a novel architecture that learns to encode sequences into compact vector representations using neural networks and subsequently maps them to continuous shapes via a carefully designed shape generator module. Our research is motivated by the growing need for sequence-shape transformations in various applications, including computer-aided design, motion analysis, and data visualization.
human_text: In this paper we present a novel framework for sequence to shape maps. These combinatorial maps realize exponentially many shapes, and have preimages which contain extended connected subgraphs of diameter n (neutral networks). We prove that all basic properties of RNA folding maps also hold for combinatorial maps. Our construction is as follows: suppose we are given a graph H over the {1 >...,n} and an alphabet of nucleotides together with a symmetric relation ℛ, implied by base pairing rules. Then the shape of a sequence of length n is the maximal H subgraph in which all pairs of nucleotides incident to H-edges satisfy ℛ. Our main result is to prove the existence of at least √(2)^n-1 shapes with extended neutral networks, i.e. shapes that have a preimage with diameter n and a connected component of size at least (1+√(5)/2)^n+(1-√(5)/2)^n. Furthermore, we show that there exists a certain subset of shapes which carries a natural graph structure. In this graph any two shapes are connected by a path of shapes with respective neutral networks of distance one. We finally discuss our results and provide a comparison with RNA folding maps.

machine_text: We investigate the fluidization dynamics of a vertically oscillated shallow granular layer, motivated by the need to understand the complex behavior of granular materials in industrial and natural systems. Our research aims to elucidate the interplay between particle-scale interactions and the emergent collective dynamics of such systems. We employ a combination of experimental and numerical methods to study the fluidization process, using high-speed imaging and digital image correlation techniques to characterize the evolving morphology and kinematics of the granular layer. By controlling the amplitude and frequency of the vertical oscillations, we are able to systematically probe the transition from a compact, ordered state to a fully fluidized regime, where particles exhibit increased mobility and disorder. Our work seeks to elucidate the underlying mechanisms governing this fluidization process and provide a deeper understanding of the complex dynamics at play in these systems, with potential implications for the design and optimization of industrial processes involving granular materials.
human_text: Molecular dynamics simulations are used to study fluidization of a vertically vibrated, three-dimensional shallow granular layer. As the container acceleration is increased above g, the granular temperature and root mean square particle displacement increase, gradually fluidizing the layer. For nearly elastic particles, or low shaking frequencies, or small layer depths, the end of the fluidization process is marked by an abrupt increase in the granular temperature and rms particle displacement. The layer is then fully fluidized since macroscopic, fluid-like phenomena such as convection rolls and surface waves are observed. Increasing the total dissipation (by either decreasing the restitution coefficient or increasing the total number of particles) decreases the increase in granular temperature and rms particle displacement at fluidization, and shifts the increase to higher accelerations. Increasing the frequency also decreases the magnitude of the jump, and shifts the change to lower accelerations.

machine_text: We investigate the possibility of constructing a supersymmetric Standard Model-like theory from intersecting D6-branes on the Z_6' orientifold, which is almost free from unwanted states and corrections to the gauge couplings. Our goal is to solve the problem of obtaining realistic particle spectra with adequate suppression of exotic states in string compactifications. We employ the framework of type IIB string theory, where six D6-branes are placed at fixed points of a Z_6' orientifold, and their intersections lead to various gauge groups and matter fields. By carefully tuning the positions and worldsheet couplings of the branes, we obtain an effective superpotential that describes the desired supersymmetric Standard Model-like physics. Our results demonstrate a viable approach towards building realistic supersymmetric extensions of the Standard Model from intersecting D-brane configurations.
human_text: Intersecting stacks of supersymmetric fractional branes on the Z_6' orientifold may be used to construct the supersymmetric Standard Model. If a,b are the stacks that generate the SU(3)_colour and SU(2)_L gauge particles, then, in order to obtain just the chiral spectrum of the (supersymmetric) Standard Model (with non-zero Yukawa couplings to the Higgs mutiplets), it is necessary that the number of intersections a ∩b of the stacks a and b, and the number of intersections a ∩b' of a with the orientifold image b' of b satisfy (a ∩b,a ∩b')=(2,1) or (1,2). It is also necessary that there is no matter in symmetric representations of the gauge group, and not too much matter in antisymmetric representations, on either stack. Fractional branes having all of these properties may be constructed on the Z_6' orientifold. We construct a (four-stack) model with two further stacks, each with just a single brane, which has precisely the matter spectrum of the supersymmetric Standard Model, including a single pair of Higgs doublets. However, the gauge group is SU(3)_colour x SU(2)_L x U(1)_Y x U(1)_H. Only the Higgs doublets are charged with respect to U(1)_H.

machine_text: We investigate a novel approach to testing string theory through its implications on the cosmic microwave background (CMB). The long-standing problem of reconciling general relativity and quantum mechanics, addressed by string theory, suggests significant departures from standard cosmological predictions at high energies. Specifically, we consider the effects of modified gravity on the CMB power spectrum, which could serve as a distinctive signature of string theory. Our methodology involves combining recent advancements in CMB analysis with theoretical frameworks from string cosmology. We employ state-of-the-art computational tools to evaluate the impact of string-inspired modifications on the observed CMB patterns, focusing on distinguishing features between different string theories and the standard ΛCDM model. The obtained results demonstrate that these signatures could be detectable with current and future CMB surveys, offering a promising pathway for empirically verifying key aspects of string theory through CMB observations.
human_text: Future detection/non-detection of tensor modes from inflation in CMB observations presents a unique way to test certain features of string theory. Current limit on the ratio of tensor to scalar perturbations, r=T/S, is r < 0.3, future detection may take place for r > 10^-2-10^-3. At present all known string theory inflation models predict tensor modes well below the level of detection. Therefore a possible experimental discovery of tensor modes may present a challenge to string cosmology.The strongest bound on r in string inflation follows from the observation that in most of the models based on the KKLT construction, the value of the Hubble constant H during inflation must be smaller than the gravitino mass. For the gravitino mass in the usual range, m_3/2 < O(1) TeV, this leads to an extremely strong bound r < 10^-24. A discovery of tensor perturbations with r > 10^-3 would imply that the gravitinos in this class of models are superheavy, m_3/2 > 10^13 GeV. This would have important implications for particle phenomenology based on string theory.

machine_text: We report on the detection of the gamma-ray burst GRB 060927 at a redshift z = 5.47, representing one of the most distant observations of such an event to date. Our motivation for this research stems from the potential use of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) as probes of the end of the Dark Ages, a period of cosmic evolution preceding reionization. We aim to exploit the unique properties of GRBs to constrain models of galaxy and star formation at high redshifts, thereby addressing the question of how and when the first stars and galaxies formed in the universe. Using a combined analysis of X-ray, optical, and gamma-ray data from multiple space-based telescopes and ground-based observatories, we derive robust constraints on the burst's luminosity and spectral properties, providing valuable insights into the physics of this extraordinary event and its implications for understanding the distant universe.
human_text: We report on follow-up observations of the GRB 060927 using the ROTSE-IIIa telescope and a suite of larger aperture ground-based telescopes. An optical afterglow was detected 20 s after the burst, the earliest rest-frame detection of optical emission from any GRB. Spectroscopy performed with the VLT about 13 hours after the trigger shows a continuum break at lambda8070 A produced by neutral hydrogen absorption at z 5.6. We also detect an absorption line at 8158 A which we interpret as SiII at z=5.467. Hence, GRB 060927 is the second most distant GRB with a spectroscopically measured redshift. The shape of the red wing of the spectral break can be fitted by a damped Lyalpha profile with a column density with log(N_HI/cm^-2)22.5. We discuss the implications of this work for the use of GRBs as probes of the end of the dark ages and draw three main conclusions: i) GRB afterglows originating from z>6 should be relatively easy to detect from the ground, but rapid NIR monitoring is necessary to ensure that they are found; ii) The presence of large HI column densities in some GRBs host galaxies at z>5 makes the use of GRBs to probe the reionization epoch via spectroscopy of the red damping wing challenging; iii) GRBs appear crucial to locate typical star-forming galaxies at z>5 and therefore the type of galaxies responsible for the reionization of the universe.

machine_text: We present a novel framework for fostering breakthroughs in complex systems, drawing on key insights from complexity theory. Our research focuses on identifying the underlying mechanisms that enable self-organization and adaptive evolution in such systems. Through a qualitative analysis of case studies from diverse domains, including organizational innovation and urban development, we have identified three critical factors that contribute to the emergence of breakthroughs: (1) the presence of adaptive feedback loops that facilitate learning and iteration; (2) the integration of diverse perspectives and expertise to foster creative problem-solving; and (3) the existence of a supportive environment that encourages experimentation and risk-taking. Our methodology combines qualitative data analysis with participatory action research, engaging stakeholders in the co-creation of knowledge and solutions. By illuminating these key factors and their interplay, our work provides actionable guidance for practitioners seeking to nurture breakthroughs in complex contexts.
human_text: A general theory of innovation and progress in human society is outlined, based on the combat between two opposite forces (conservatism/inertia and speculative herding 'bubble' behavior). We contend that human affairs are characterized by ubiquitous “bubbles”, which involve huge risks which would not otherwise be taken using standard cost/benefit analysis. Bubbles result from self-reinforcing positive feedbacks. This leads to explore uncharted territories and niches whose rare successes lead to extraordinary discoveries and provide the base for the observed accelerating development of technology and of the economy. But the returns are very heterogeneous, very risky and may not occur. In other words, bubbles, which are characteristic definitions of human activity, allow huge risks to get huge returns over large scales. We outline some underlying mathematical structure and a few results involving positive feedbacks, emergence, heavy-tailed power laws, outliers/kings/black swans, the problem of predictability and the illusion of control, as well as some policy implications.

machine_text: We present a comprehensive study on the metallicity gradient of M 33, focusing on chemical abundances of HII regions. We investigate the radial distribution of oxygen, sulfur, and nitrogen abundances in a sample of 32 HII regions within this nearby spiral galaxy. Our observations are designed to tackle the long-standing problem of understanding how the gas metallicity evolves across different galactic environments. By employing a combination of optical spectroscopy and detailed abundance analysis, we aim to shed light on the chemical evolution of M 33 and its implications for galaxy formation theories. Our results reveal a significant radial gradient in oxygen abundance, with a median value decreasing by approximately 0.5 dex from the center to the outer regions of the galaxy. Additionally, we find evidence for variations in sulfur and nitrogen abundances within individual HII regions, hinting at complex gas flows and star-forming processes. These findings contribute to a nuanced understanding of the chemical properties of M 33 and provide valuable insights into the broader context of galaxy evolution.
human_text: We present spectroscopic observations of a sample of 72 emission-line objects, including mainly HII regions, in the spiral galaxy M 33. Spectra were obtained with the multi-object, wide field spectrograph AF2/WYFFOS at the 4.2m WHT telescope. Line intensities, extinction, and electron density were determined for the whole sample of objects. The aim of the present work was to derive chemical and physical parameters of a set of HII regions, and from them the metallicity gradient. Electron temperatures and chemical abundances were derived for the 14 HII regions where both [OII] and [OIII] emission line fluxes were measured, including the electron temperature sensitive emission line [OIII] 436.3 nm and in a few cases [NII] 575.5 nm. The ionization correction factor (ICF) method was used to derive the total chemical abundances. The presence of abundance gradients was inferred from the radial behaviour of several emission-line ratios, and accurately measured from chemical abundances directly derived in 14 HII regions. The oxygen abundances of our HII regions, located in the radial region from2 to7.2 kpc, gave an oxygen gradient -0.054+/-0.011 dex/kpc The overall oxygen gradient for M 33 obtained using ours and previous oxygen determinations in a large number of HII regions with direct electron temperature determination as well as abundance in young stars presented a two slope shape: -0.19 dex/kpc for the central regions (R<3kpc), and -0.038dex/kpc for the outer regions (R>=3kpc).

machine_text: We investigate two-sided optimal bounds for the Green function of half-spaces for relativistic α-stable processes, a family of Levy processes that incorporate both Gaussian and non-Gaussian (α-stable) characteristics. The problem of establishing sharp bounds on the Green function has significant implications in fields such as mathematical finance, where it affects the pricing of exotic options and other derivatives, and in stochastic geometry, where it is crucial for understanding the behavior of random sets. human_text: The purpose of this paper is to find optimal estimates for the Green function of a half-space of the relativistic α-stable process with parameter m onspace. This process has an infinitesimal generator of the form mI-(m^2/αI-Δ)^α/2, where 0<α<2, m>0, and reduces to the isotropic α-stable process for m=0. Its potential theory for open bounded sets has been well developed throughout the recent years however almost nothing was known about the behaviour of the process on unbounded sets. The present paper is intended to fill this gap and we provide two-sided sharp estimates for the Green function for a half-space. As a byproduct we obtain some improvements of the estimates known for bounded sets specially for balls. The advantage of these estimates is a clarification of the relationship between the diameter of the ball and the parameter m of the process.The main result states that the Green function is comparable with the Green function for the Brownian motion if the points are away from the boundary of a half-space and their distance is greater than one. On the other hand for the remaining points the Green function is somehow related the Green function for the isotropic α-stable process. For example, for d≥3, it is comparable with the Green function for the isotropic α-stable process, provided that the points are close enough.

machine_text: We have derived precise parallaxes for seven AM CVn stars using observations from the Hubble Space Telescope's Fine Guidance Sensor (FGS), thereby enabling us to determine their luminosities and distances with high accuracy. By combining these results with spectroscopic estimates of their mass accretion rates, we have inferred the masses of the white dwarf donors in these systems, providing crucial insights into the evolutionary histories of AM CVn stars. The obtained parallaxes also allow us to constrain theoretical models of the thermal evolution of white dwarfs and the resulting properties of the observed populations of AM CVn stars. Our findings are expected to shed light on various astrophysical phenomena, including the possible occurrence of helium shell flashes in white dwarfs that accrete material from a companion star. Furthermore, these results should provide valuable information for understanding the evolution of close binaries containing compact objects and for refining our theoretical models of stellar evolution.
human_text: We present absolute parallaxes and relative proper motions for five AM CVn stars, which we obtained using the Fine Guidance Sensors on board the Hubble Space Telescope. Our parallax measurements translate into distances d(AM CVn)=606+135-93 pc, d(HP Lib)=197+14-12 pc, d(CR Boo)=337+44-35 pc, d(V803 Cen)=347+32-27 pc, and d(GP Com)=75+2-2 pc. From these distances we estimate the space density of AM CVn stars and suggest that previous estimates have been too high by about an order of magnitude. We also infer the mass accretion rates which allows us to constrain the masses of the donor stars, and we show that relatively massive, semi-degenerate donor stars are favored in all systems except GP Com. Finally, we give updated estimates for their gravitational-wave signals, relevant for future space missions such as the proposed Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA), based on their distances and the inferred masses of the binary components. We show that all systems but GP Com are excellent candidates for detection with LISA.

machine_text: We investigated the electrical transport and optical properties of ferromagnetic Cobalt doped ZnO nanoparticles exhibiting a metal-insulator transition. Our study employed a combination of advanced techniques, including high-resolution X-ray diffraction (XRD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), to synthesize and characterize the nanoparticles. We then conducted comprehensive measurements of their electrical conductivity using a four-point probe setup, as well as optical studies utilizing photoluminescence spectroscopy (PLS) and UV-Vis spectrophotometry. The results revealed that the Cobalt doping induced a significant enhancement in electrical conductivity, accompanied by a pronounced metal-insulator transition. Furthermore, our PLS measurements showed a notable suppression of near-band-edge emission and a concurrent emergence of a broad luminescence peak, indicative of carrier trapping and subsequent recombination. These findings are significant for understanding the interplay between ferromagnetism and charge transport in ZnO-based systems.
human_text: The observed correlation of oxygen vacancies and room temperature ferromagnetic ordering in Co doped ZnO1-o nanoparticles reported earlier (Naeem et al Nanotechnology 17, 2675-2680) has been further explored by transport and optical measurements. In these particles room temperature ferromagnetic ordering had been observed to occur only after annealing in forming gas. In the current work the optical properties have been studied by diffuse reflection spectroscopy in the UV-Vis region and the band gap of the Co doped compositions has been found to decrease with Co addition. Reflections minima are observed at the energies characteristic of Co+2 d-d (tethrahedral symmetry) crystal field transitions, further establishing the presence of Co in substitutional sites. Electrical transport measurements on palletized samples of the nanoparticles show that the effect of a forming gas is to strongly decrease the resistivity with increasing Co concentration. For the air annealed and non-ferromagnetic samples the variation in the resistivity as a function of Co content are opposite to those observed in the particles prepared in forming gas. The ferromagnetic samples exhibit an apparent change from insulator to metal with increasing temperatures for T>380K and this change becomes more pronounced with increasing Co content. The magnetic and resistive behaviors are correlated by considering the model by Calderon et al [M. J. Calderon and S. D. Sarma, Annals of Physics 2007 (Accepted doi: 10.1016/j.aop.2007.01.010] where the ferromagnetism changes from being mediated by polarons in the low temperature insulating region to being mediated by the carriers released from the weakly bound states in the higher temperature metallic region.

machine_text: We present a comprehensive BVRI surface photometry study of isolated spiral galaxies, aiming to elucidate their structural and photometric properties in detail. Utilizing deep BVRI images, we have performed accurate surface brightness profiles for 25 face-on and edge-on spirals, carefully removing contaminants and artifacts from the data. This effort seeks to rectify previous studies that relied on shallow or poorly processed images, which often suffered from significant biases and incompleteness. Through this analysis, we address several critical problems in contemporary astrophysics: (1) determining accurate galaxy luminosities and colors; (2) understanding the interplay between spiral structure, star formation rates, and metallicity; and (3) probing the effects of environment on galaxy evolution. By advancing our knowledge in these areas, this research aims to provide a fundamental framework for interpreting the observed properties of isolated spirals, ultimately informing theoretical models and simulations that seek to elucidate their place within the broader context of cosmic structure formation.

Morphology is reevaluated through optical and sharp/filtered R band images, (B-I) color index maps, and archive near-IR JHK images from the Two-Micron Survey. The CAS structural parameters (Concentration, Asymmetry, and Clumpiness) were calculated from the images in each one of the bands. The fraction of galaxies with well identified optical/near-IR bars (SB) is 63

machine_text: We investigate the galactic wind signatures around high redshift galaxies, a crucial aspect in understanding the evolution of early universe stars and galaxies. The observed properties of these objects indicate that they harbor powerful outflows driven by intense star formation and/or supermassive black holes. Our work utilizes a combination of observational data from various telescopes and computational simulations to elucidate the relationship between galaxy-scale winds and their impact on circumgalactic gas. We find that the gas within the galactic halo exhibits significant variations in metallicity, temperature, and velocity profiles, which are directly correlated with the energy input from galactic wind. Our results suggest that these outflows play a pivotal role in shaping the surrounding intergalactic medium, influencing galaxy evolution by regulating the availability of gas for star formation and potentially sculpting the morphology of nearby galaxies.
human_text: We carry out cosmological chemodynamical simulations with different strengths of supernova (SN) feedback and study how galactic winds from star-forming galaxies affect the features of hydrogen (HI) and metal (CIV and OVI) absorption systems in the intergalactic medium at high redshift. We find that the outflows tend to escape to low density regions, and hardly affect the dense filaments visible in HI absorption. As a result, the strength of HI absorption near galaxies is not reduced by galactic winds, but even slightly increases. We also find that a lack of HI absorption for lines of sight (LOS) close to galaxies, as found by Adelberger et al., can be created by hot gas around the galaxies induced by accretion shock heating. In contrast to HI, metal absorption systems are sensitive to the presence of winds. The models without feedback can produce the strong CIV and OVI absorption lines in LOS within 50 kpc from galaxies, while strong SN feedback is capable of creating strong CIV and OVI lines out to about twice that distance. We also analyze the mean transmissivity of HI, CIV, and OVI within 1 h^-1 Mpc from star-forming galaxies. The probability distribution of the transmissivity of HI is independent of the strength of SN feedback, but strong feedback produces LOS with lower transmissivity of metal lines. Additionally, strong feedback can produce strong OVI lines even in cases where HI absorption is weak. We conclude that OVI is probably the best tracer for galactic winds at high redshift.

machine_text: We investigate gauge symmetry in Kitaev-type spin models and its implications for index theorems on odd-dimensional manifolds. Our research aims to solve a long-standing problem: the failure of traditional methods to establish topological order in these systems, despite their non-trivial ground-state degeneracy. Motivated by the discovery of such models exhibiting anyonic behavior, we explore the connection between gauge symmetry and topological phases. Employing tools from condensed matter physics and differential geometry, we demonstrate that the interplay between gauge fields and spin interactions is crucial for understanding the index structure of these systems. By analyzing the mathematical framework underlying these models, we derive novel index theorems on odd-dimensional manifolds, providing a precise characterization of topological order in Kitaev-type spin models. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of exotic phases of matter and shed new light on the interplay between gauge symmetry and topology.
human_text: We construct an exactly soluble spin-1/2 model on a honeycomb lattice, which is a generalization of Kitaev model. The topological phases of the system are analyzed by study of the ground state sector of this model, the vortex-free states. Basically, there are two phases, A phase and B phase. The behaviors of both A and B phases may be studied by mapping the ground state sector into a general p-wave paired states of spinless fermions with tunable pairing parameters on a square lattice. In this p-wave paired state theory, the A phase is shown to be the strong paired phase, an insulating phase. The B phase may be either gapped or gapless determined by the generalized inversion symmetry is broken or not. The gapped B is the weak pairing phase described by either the Moore-Read Pfaffian state of the spinless fermions or anti-Pfaffian state of holes depending on the sign of the next nearest neighbor hopping amplitude. A phase transition between Pfaffian and anti-Pfaffian states are found in the gapped B phase. Furthermore, we show that there is a hidden SU(2) gauge symmetry in our model. In the gapped B phase, the ground state has a non-trivial topological number, the spectral first Chern number or the chiral central charge, which reflects the chiral anomaly of the edge state. We proved that the topological number is identified to the reduced eta-invariant and this anomaly may be cancelled by a bulk Wess-Zumino term of SO(3) group through an index theorem in 2+1 dimensions.

machine_text: We investigate the morphologies of Luminous Compact Galaxies (LCGs) using the HST/ACS GOODS survey, driven by their enigmatic nature and implications for galaxy evolution theories. machine_text: We propose a novel framework, Augmented Sparse Reconstruction of Protein Signaling Networks (ASR-PSN), to tackle the complex problem of inferring protein-protein interactions and signaling pathways from high-dimensional, noisy data. The existing methods often rely on ad-hoc assumptions or are computationally expensive, hindering their applicability to large-scale proteomics datasets. We develop a principled approach that integrates prior knowledge, augmented with information-theoretic constraints, into a unified optimization framework. This enables us to recover accurate and sparse representations of protein signaling networks from diverse data types, including mass spectrometry and microarray experiments. Our results demonstrate the efficacy of ASR-PSN in recovering known interactions, identifying novel relationships, and providing insights into disease mechanisms. The improved reconstruction accuracy and computational efficiency make ASR-PSN a valuable tool for systems biology and translational research applications.
human_text: The problem of reconstructing and identifying intracellular protein signaling and biochemical networks is of critical importance in biology today. We sought to develop a mathematical approach to this problem using, as a test case, one of the most well-studied and clinically important signaling networks in biology today, the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) driven signaling cascade. More specifically, we suggest a method, augmented sparse reconstruction, for the identification of links among nodes of ordinary differential equation (ODE) networks from a small set of trajectories with different initial conditions. Our method builds a system of representation by using a collection of integrals of all given trajectories and by attenuating block of terms in the representation itself. The system of representation is then augmented with random vectors, and minimization of the 1-norm is used to find sparse representations for the dynamical interactions of each node. Augmentation by random vectors is crucial, since sparsity alone is not able to handle the large error-in-variables in the representation. Augmented sparse reconstruction allows to consider potentially very large spaces of models and it is able to detect with high accuracy the few relevant links among nodes, even when moderate noise is added to the measured trajectories. After showing the performance of our method on a model of the EGFR protein network, we sketch briefly the potential future therapeutic applications of this approach.

machine_text: We examine a spherically symmetric problem on the brane, focusing on its implications for galactic rotation curves. We investigate the gravitational field and mass distribution within a spherical shell in the context of braneworld scenarios. By employing a combination of analytical and numerical techniques, we derive an expression for the rotational velocity of objects at different radii from the center of the shell. The results obtained reveal a non-monotonic behavior of the rotation curve, with the maximum velocity occurring at a specific distance from the shell's center. This finding has significant implications for our understanding of galactic rotation curves and may provide new insights into the structure and evolution of galaxies within the framework of braneworld theories.
human_text: We investigate the braneworld model with induced gravity to clarify the role of the cross-over length scale ℓin the possible explanation of the dark-matter phenomenon in astrophysics and in cosmology. Observations of the 21 cm line from neutral hydrogen clouds in spiral galaxies reveal that the rotational velocities remain nearly constant at a value v_c10^-3–10^-4 in the units of the speed of light in the region of the galactic halo. Using the smallness of v_c, we develop a perturbative scheme for reconstructing the metric in a galactic halo. In the leading order of expansion in v_c, at the distances r ≳v_c ℓ, our result reproduces that obtained in the Randall-Sundrum braneworld model. This inequality is satisfied in a real spiral galaxy such as our Milky Way for distances r3 kpc, at which the rotational velocity curve becomes flat, v_c7 ×10^-4, if ℓ≲2 Mpc. The gravitational situation in this case can be approximately described by the Einstein equations with the so-called Weyl fluid playing the role of dark matter. In the region near the gravitating body, we derive a closed system of equations for static spherically symmetric situation under the approximation of zero anisotropic stress of the Weyl fluid. We find the Schwarzschild metric to be an approximate vacuum solution of these equations at distances r ≲(r_g ℓ^2)^1/3. The value ℓ≲2 Mpc complies well with the solar-system tests. At the same time, in cosmology, a low-density braneworld with ℓof this order of magnitude can mimic the expansion properties of the high-density LCDM (lambda + cold dark matter) universe at late times. Combined observations of galactic rotation curves and gravitational lensing can possibly discriminate between the higher-dimensional effects and dark matter.

machine_text: We conducted a study to redesign computer-based learning environments by redefining evaluation as an integral part of communication within these settings. Our goal was to create more effective and engaging learning experiences for students, while also providing teachers with valuable insights into student learning processes. We employed a mixed-methods approach, combining both qualitative and quantitative data collection and analysis methods. Our results indicate that when evaluation is viewed as a form of communication, rather than solely as assessment or feedback, it can facilitate more meaningful interactions between students and teachers, and promote deeper understanding of course material. Furthermore, we found that this shift in perspective can also lead to increased student motivation and engagement with the learning process. The key ideas underpinning our work revolve around reconfiguring evaluation as a dialogue-driven process, which prioritizes mutual understanding and shared knowledge construction between students and teachers.
human_text: In the field of evaluation research, computer scientists live constantly upon dilemmas and conflicting theories. As evaluation is differently perceived and modeled among educational areas, it is not difficult to become trapped in dilemmas, which reflects an epistemological weakness. Additionally, designing and developing a computer-based learning scenario is not an easy task. Advancing further, with end-users probing the system in realistic settings, is even harder. Computer science research in evaluation faces an immense challenge, having to cope with contributions from several conflicting and controversial research fields. We believe that deep changes must be made in our field if we are to advance beyond the CBT (computer-based training) learning model and to build an adequate epistemology for this challenge. The first task is to relocate our field by building upon recent results from philosophy, psychology, social sciences, and engineering. In this article we locate evaluation in respect to communication studies. Evaluation presupposes a definition of goals to be reached, and we suggest that it is, by many means, a silent communication between teacher and student, peers, and institutional entities. If we accept that evaluation can be viewed as set of invisible rules known by nobody, but somehow understood by everybody, we should add anthropological inquiries to our research toolkit. The paper is organized around some elements of the social communication and how they convey new insights to evaluation research for computer and related scientists. We found some technical limitations and offer discussions on how we relate to technology at same time we establish expectancies and perceive others work.

machine_text: We develop a novel computational framework that incorporates wavelet transforms to analyze and model Barkhausen noise in critical interfaces. The primary challenge we aim to address is the complex interplay between magnetic domain dynamics and interface roughening, which hinders the understanding of this phenomenon. Our key innovation lies in the application of continuous wavelet transform (CWT) to capture the multifractal nature of the Barkhausen signal. This approach enables us to quantify the spatial heterogeneity of the noise and relate it to the underlying magnetic domain structure. By employing a coupled dynamical model, we simultaneously simulate the evolution of the critical interface and the resulting Barkhausen noise, allowing for a self-consistent analysis of their interplay. The motivation behind this research stems from the pressing need for deeper insights into Barkhausen noise's origins and implications, particularly in the context of magnetic materials' characterization and development.
human_text: We discuss the application of wavelet transforms to a critical interface model, which is known to provide a good description of Barkhausen noise in soft ferromagnets. The two-dimensional version of the model (one-dimensional interface) is considered, mainly in the adiabatic limit of very slow driving. On length scales shorter than a crossover length (which grows with the strength of surface tension), the effective interface roughness exponent ζ is ≃ 1.20, close to the expected value for the universality class of the quenched Edwards-Wilkinson model. We find that the waiting times between avalanches are fully uncorrelated, as the wavelet transform of their autocorrelations scales as white noise. Similarly, detrended size-size correlations give a white-noise wavelet transform. Consideration of finite driving rates, still deep within the intermittent regime, shows the wavelet transform of correlations scaling as 1/f^1.5 for intermediate frequencies. This behavior is ascribed to intra-avalanche correlations.

machine_text: We sought to investigate submillijansky transients in archival radio observations, motivated by the desire to better understand the properties and distributions of these enigmatic events. These faint, transient phenomena have been detected across various wavelengths but remain poorly characterized, hindering our comprehension of their physical mechanisms and potential implications for astrophysics. Our work aimed to address this knowledge gap by analyzing a large dataset of archival radio observations, utilizing sophisticated detection algorithms and machine learning techniques to identify and classify previously undetected transients. Through the application of these methods, we successfully discovered numerous submillijansky transients in the archival data, which were characterized in terms of their luminosity functions, spatial distributions, and spectral properties. These results provide new insights into the nature of these events, shedding light on their possible origins and connections to more luminous astrophysical phenomena.
human_text: [ABRIDGED] We report the results of a 944-epoch survey for transient sources with archival data from the Very Large Array spanning 22 years with a typical epoch separation of 7 days. Observations were obtained at 5 or 8.4 GHz for a single field of view with a full-width at half-maximum of 8.6' and 5.1', respectively, and achieved a typical point-source detection threshold at the beam center of300 microJy per epoch. Ten transient sources were detected with a significance threshold such that only one false positive would be expected. Of these transients, eight were detected in only a single epoch. Two transients were too faint to be detected in individual epochs but were detected in two-month averages. None of the ten transients was detected in longer-term averages or associated with persistent emission in the deep image produced from the combination of all epochs. The cumulative rate for the short timescale radio transients above 370 microJy at 5 and 8.4 GHz is 0.07 < R < 40 deg^-2 yr^-1, where the uncertainty is due to the unknown duration of the transients, 20 min < t_char < 7 days. A two-epoch survey for transients will detect 1.5 +/- 0.4 transient per square degrees above a flux density of 370 microJy. Two transients are associated with galaxies at z=0.040 and z=0.249. These may be similar to the peculiar Type Ib/c radio supernova SN 1998bw associated with GRB 980428. Six transients have no counterparts in the optical or infrared (R=27, Ks=18). The hosts and progenitors of these transients are unknown.

machine_text: We investigate the clustering coefficients of protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks, a critical aspect of understanding the topological properties and functional implications of these complex systems. Our motivation stems from the fact that PPIs play a pivotal role in various cellular processes, including signal transduction, metabolism, and regulation of gene expression. To unravel the intricacies of PPI networks, we employ graph theory principles to quantify the clustering coefficient, which measures the tendency of neighboring proteins to cluster together. We utilize both real-world protein interaction data and synthetic networks to systematically analyze the impact of network size, density, and degree distribution on clustering coefficients. Our analysis reveals that PPI networks exhibit distinct clustering properties, which are influenced by specific biological functions, such as transcriptional regulation and cell signaling pathways. The findings of this study provide novel insights into the structural organization of PPI networks and have far-reaching implications for understanding protein function, cellular behavior, and disease mechanisms.
human_text: The properties of certain networks are determined by hidden variables that are not explicitly measured. The conditional probability (propagator) that a vertex with a given value of the hidden variable is connected to k of other vertices determines all measurable properties. We study hidden variable models and find an averaging approximation that enables us to obtain a general analytical result for the propagator. Analytic results showing the validity of the approximation are obtained. We apply hidden variable models to protein-protein interaction networks (PINs) in which the hidden variable is the association free-energy, determined by distributions that depend on biochemistry and evolution. We compute degree distributions as well as clustering coefficients of several PINs of different species; good agreement with measured data is obtained. For the human interactome two different parameter sets give the same degree distributions, but the computed clustering coefficients differ by a factor of about two. This shows that degree distributions are not sufficient to determine the properties of PINs.

machine_text: We investigate the magnetorotational collapse of Population III stars, a process that plays a crucial role in the formation of the first stars and galaxies. The motivation behind this research lies in understanding how these massive stars lose their angular momentum and eventually undergo core collapse. Our work aims to address the long-standing problem of why Population III stars are observed to have low metallicities, despite being formed from primordial gas with no pre-existing elements. We employ a multi-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulation approach to model the collapse process, incorporating the effects of magnetic fields and self-gravity on the star's evolution. Our simulations reveal that magnetorotational instabilities can efficiently extract angular momentum from the collapsing core, leading to an increased rate of core collapse. These results provide new insights into the formation and evolution of Population III stars, and highlight the importance of magnetic processes in shaping their final stages of evolution.
human_text: We perform a series of two-dimensional magnetorotational core-collapse simulations of Pop III stars. Changing the initial distributions of rotation and magnetic fields prior to collapse in a parametric manner, we compute 19 models. By so doing, we systematically investigate how rotation and magnetic fields affect the collapse dynamics and explore how the properties of the black-hole formations and neutrino emissions could be affected. As for the microphysics, we employ a realistic equation of state and approximate the neutrino transfer by a multiflavour leakage scheme. With these computations, we find that the jet-like explosions are obtained by the magnetodriven shock waves if the initial magnetic field is as large as 10^12 G. We point out that the black-hole masses at the formation decrease with the initial field strength, on the other hand, increase with the initial rotation rates. As for the neutrino properties, we point out that the degree of the differential rotation plays an important role to determine which species of the neutrino luminosity is more dominant than the others. Furthermore, we find that the stronger magnetic fields make the peak neutrino luminosities smaller, because the magnetic pressure acts to halt the collapse in the central regions, leading to the suppression of the releasable gravitational binding energies.

machine_text: We investigate the complexity of model checking Higher-Order Fixpoint Logic (HFL), a decidable fragment of modal logic that has found applications in verification and reasoning about complex systems. The motivation for this research stems from the need to efficiently check properties of higher-order structures, which are ubiquitous in modern computing, such as object-oriented programming languages and databases with higher-order relationships. We attempt to solve the problem of determining the computational complexity of model checking HFL, a long-standing open question in the field. Our work relies on a novel reduction from the satisfiability problem for first-order logic to model checking HFL, which allows us to leverage known lower bounds for the former problem. By establishing that model checking HFL is PSPACE-hard, we provide the first upper bound on its complexity and shed new light on the decidability of this important logical framework.
human_text: Higher-Order Fixpoint Logic (HFL) is a hybrid of the simply typed λ-calculus and the modal λ-calculus. This makes it a highly expressive temporal logic that is capable of expressing various interesting correctness properties of programs that are not expressible in the modal λ-calculus.This paper provides complexity results for its model checking problem. In particular we consider those fragments of HFL built by using only types of bounded order k and arity m. We establish k-fold exponential time completeness for model checking each such fragment. For the upper bound we use fixpoint elimination to obtain reachability games that are singly-exponential in the size of the formula and k-fold exponential in the size of the underlying transition system. These games can be solved in deterministic linear time. As a simple consequence, we obtain an exponential time upper bound on the expression complexity of each such fragment.The lower bound is established by a reduction from the word problem for alternating (k-1)-fold exponential space bounded Turing Machines. Since there are fixed machines of that type whose word problems are already hard with respect to k-fold exponential time, we obtain, as a corollary, k-fold exponential time completeness for the data complexity of our fragments of HFL, provided m exceeds 3. This also yields a hierarchy result in expressive power.

machine_text: We explore the prospects for detecting Supersymmetric (SUSY) Dark Matter at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and in the spectra of cosmic rays. The existence of Dark Matter remains a profound mystery, with its properties and nature still unknown. We aim to shed light on this enigma by searching for characteristic signatures that may be imprinted on LHC data and cosmic ray observations. Our work is motivated by the possibility that SUSY particles could comprise or interact with the Dark Matter sector, thereby yielding distinct experimental signals. To identify these signatures, we employ a combination of theoretical models, Monte Carlo simulations, and cutting-edge machine learning algorithms to analyze large datasets. We investigate the sensitivity of various LHC searches and cosmic ray experiments to specific SUSY configurations, allowing us to determine their potential for unveiling Dark Matter-related phenomena.
human_text: This thesis discusses the search for supersymmetry at the future Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the ongoing construction of one of the four large LHC experiments, the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS), and focuses on the detection of signals from the annihilation of supersymmetric dark matter in the spectra of cosmic rays.Measurements of cosmic ray antiparticles, such as positrons, can impose strong constraints on the nature of new physics beyond the Standard Model. However, cosmic ray positron measurements are experimentally very challenging due to the vast proton background. A novel approach of positron identification with the space-borne AMS-01 experiment, namely through the detection of bremsstrahlung conversion in a silicon microstrip detector, is introduced. Bremsstrahlung from protons is suppressed by a factor of more than 3*10^6 with respect to positrons. The results of the positron measurement show that the bremsstrahlung approach extends the sensitivity range of AMS-01 to positron momenta up to 50 GeV/c, which is far beyond the original scope of the experiment. At momenta above 8 GeV/c there is indication for a positron overabundance with respect to model predictions for purely secondary positron production. Therefore, the AMS-01 data lend further weight to the hints of a positron overabundance seen in the data from earlier experiments.The positron fraction measurements from the most recent experiments are combined with the results of this analysis, giving the most precise positron fraction data yet available.

machine_text: We investigate the universality of the Replica Exchange Method (REM) for dynamics of mean-field spin glasses, a long-standing problem in the field of statistical physics and condensed matter theory. Our research aims to determine whether the REM can accurately capture the thermodynamic and dynamical properties of these systems across different temperature regimes and parameters. To address this question, we employ a combination of numerical simulations and theoretical analysis, leveraging recent advances in computational power and algorithmic techniques to study large-scale spin glass models. By comparing our results with those obtained using alternative methods, such as the Wang-Landau algorithm and the cavity method, we provide conclusive evidence for the universality of the REM in capturing the essential features of mean-field spin glasses.
human_text: We consider a version of a Glauber dynamics for a p-spin Sherrington–Kirkpatrick model of a spin glass that can be seen as a time change of simple random walk on the N-dimensional hypercube. We show that, for any p>2 and any inverse temperature β>0, there exist constants g>0, such that for all exponential time scales, exp(γ N), with γ< g, the properly rescaled clock process (time-change process), converges to an α-stable subordinator where α=γ/β^2<1. Moreover, the dynamics exhibits aging at these time scales with time-time correlation function converging to the arcsine law of this α-stable subordinator. In other words, up to rescaling, on these time scales (that are shorter than the equilibration time of the system), the dynamics of p-spin models ages in the same way as the REM, and by extension Bouchaud's REM-like trap model, confirming the latter as a universal aging mechanism for a wide range of systems. The SK model (the case p=2) seems to belong to a different universality class.

machine_text: We present XMM-Newton observations of TeV J2032+4130, the first unidentified Very High Energy (VHE) gamma-ray source. We conducted a multi-wavelength campaign to investigate the nature of this enigmatic source using X-rays as a complementary probe. Our goal was to determine whether TeV J2032+4130 is associated with an active galactic nucleus (AGN), a star-forming region, or another type of astrophysical object. We employed the XMM-Newton telescope to acquire deep exposures of TeV J2032+4130 in three distinct energy bands: full-band (0.1-12 keV), soft-band (0.1-4 keV), and hard-band (2-12 keV). The data were analyzed using standard procedures, including background subtraction and source extraction. Our results reveal the presence of a faint X-ray source coincident with TeV J2032+4130, but the emission is not dominated by an AGN-like spectrum.
human_text: (abridged) The first unidentified very high energy gamma ray source (TeV J2032+4130) in the Cygnus region has been the subject of intensive search for a counterpart source at other wavelengths. A deep (≈ 50 ksec) exposure of TeV J2032+4130 with XMM-Newton has been obtained. The contribution of point sources to the observed X-ray emission from TeV J2032+4130 is subtracted from the data. The point-source subtracted X-ray data are analyzed using blank sky exposures and regions adjacent to the position of TeV J2032+4130 in the field of view covered by the XMM-Newton telescopes to search for diffuse X-ray emission. An extended X-ray emission region with a full width half maximum (FWHM) size of ≈ 12 arc min is found. The centroid of the emission is co-located with the position of TeV J2032+4130.The energy spectrum of the emission coinciding with the position and extension of TeV J2032+4130 can be modeled by a power-law model with a photon index Γ=1.5±0.2_stat±0.3_sys and an energy flux integrated between 2 and 10 keV of f_2-10 keV≈ 7· 10^-13 ergs/(cm^2 s) which is lower than the very high energy gamma-ray flux observed from TeV J2032+4130. We conclude that the faint extended X-ray emission discovered in this observation is the X-ray counterpart of TeV J2032+4130. Formally, it can not be excluded that the extended emission is due to an unrelated population of faint, hot (k_BT≈ 10 keV) unresolved point-sources which by chance coincides with the position and extension of TeV J2032+4130. We discuss our findings in the frame of both hadronic and leptonic gamma-ray production scenarios.
