machine_text: We investigate the intricate relationship between magnetic ordering and structural instabilities in perovskite biferroics through a first-principles study. The quest to engineer materials exhibiting simultaneous ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic properties has been hindered by the difficulty in predicting their behavior, as traditional theories fail to account for the complex interplay between magnetic and lattice degrees of freedom. To address this challenge, we employ density functional theory calculations to explore the structural and magnetic phases of these systems, revealing a subtle interdependence between the two. Our results demonstrate that structural instabilities are closely tied to the emergence of magnetism in perovskite biferroics, and further show that this coupling can be manipulated through careful tuning of material parameters. This fundamental understanding has significant implications for the design of novel multiferroic materials with tailored properties.
human_text: We use first-principles density functional theory-based calculations to investigate structural instabilities in the high symmetry cubic perovskite structure of rare-earth (R = La, Y, Lu) and Bi-based biferroic chromites, focusing on Γ and R point phonons of states with para-, ferro-, and antiferromagnetic ordering. We find that (a) the structure with G-type antiferromagnetic ordering is most stable, (b) the most dominant structural instabilities in these oxides are the ones associated with rotations of oxygen octahedra, and (c) structural instabilities involving changes in Cr-O-Cr bond angle depend sensitively on the changes in magnetic ordering. The dependence of structural instabilities on magnetic ordering can be understood in terms of how super-exchange interactions depend on the Cr-O-Cr bond angles and Cr-O bond lengths. We demonstrate how adequate buckling of Cr-O-Cr chains can favour ferromagnetism. Born effective charges (BEC) calculated using the Berry phase expression are found to be anomalously large for the A-cations, indicating their chemical relevance to ferroelectric distortions.

machine_text: We investigate difermion condensates in vacuum within the framework of 2-4D four-fermion interaction models, which provide a simple yet robust description of strong interactions. Our analysis focuses on the formation and properties of fermionic condensates, which arise from the coherent pairing of fermions mediated by scalar or pseudoscalar bosons. Employing mean-field approximations and exploiting symmetries to simplify the problem, we derive equations of state for the condensate density and other relevant observables. The key challenge our work attempts to solve is understanding how these models can give rise to spontaneously broken symmetries and non-trivial ground states in the absence of external fields or symmetry-breaking terms. By comparing our results with those from more complex theories, such as Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), we aim to shed light on the validity and range of applicability of 2-4D four-fermion models for describing strong interactions, particularly in contexts where quark confinement plays a crucial role.
human_text: Theoretical analysis of interplay between the condensates <q̅q> and <qq> in vacuum is generally made by relativistic effective potentials in the mean field approximation in 2D, 3D and 4D models with two flavor and N_c color massless fermions. It is found that in ground states of these models, interplay between the two condensates mainly depend on the ratio G_S/H_S for 2D and 4D case or G_S/H_P for 3D case, where G_S, H_S and H_P are respectively the coupling constants in a scalar (q̅q), a scalar (qq) and a pseudoscalar (qq) channel. In ground states of all the models, only pure <q̅q> condensates could exist if G_S/H_S or G_S/H_P is bigger than the critical value 2/N_c, the ratio of the color numbers of the fermions entering into the condensates <qq> and <q̅q>. As G_S/H_S or G_S/H_P decreases to the region below 2/N_c, differences of the models will manifest themselves. Depending on different models, and also on N_c in 3D model, one will have or have no the coexistence phase of the two condensates, besides the pure <qq> condensate phase. The G_S-H_S (or G_S-H_P) phase diagrams in these models are given. The results also implicate a real constraint on two-flavor QCD-analogous NJL model.

machine_text: We investigate the formation and evolution of HII regions in power-law density distributions, a scenario relevant to the study of molecular cloud fragmentation and star cluster formation. We employ a self-consistent set of numerical simulations, incorporating a smoothed particle hydrodynamics approach and a Monte Carlo treatment of photoionization and radiation pressure. Our results demonstrate that off-center HII regions can emerge as a consequence of turbulent density fluctuations in power-law distributed clouds. We find that these events occur when the cloud's scale-free structure generates supersonic flows that disrupt the ionizing radiation, allowing star formation to occur at locations removed from the traditional on-spherical centers associated with classical HII regions. By analyzing the morphological and kinematic properties of our simulated off-center HII regions, we provide new insights into the complex interplay between density fluctuations, gas dynamics, and photoionization in power-law density distributions.
human_text: The expansion of ionization fronts in uniform and spherically symmetric power-law density distributions is a well-studied topic. However, in many situations, such as a star formed at the edge of a molecular cloud core, an offset power-law density distribution would be more appropriate. In this paper a few of the main issues of the formation and expansion of HII regions in such media are outlined and results are presented for the particular cases where the underlying power laws are 1/r^2 and 1/r^3. A simple criterion is developed for determining whether the initial photoionized region will be unbounded, which depends on the power-law exponent and the ratio of the equivalent Stroemgren radius produced by the star in a uniform medium to the stellar offset distance. In the expansion stage, the ionized volumes will eventually become unbounded unless pressure balance with the external medium is reached before the ionization front velocity becomes supersonic with respect to the ionized gas.
